title: Study Safety and Efficacy of Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) and Cervical Deep Lymphoid-venous Anastomosis (LVA) in Patients With Severe Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: To investigate the safety of deep brain stimulation (DBS) and cervical deep lymphoid-venous anastomosis (LVA) in the treatment of severe Alzheimer's disease (AD); to investigate the effectiveness of DBS and LVA in the treatment of severe AD, i.e., effects of deep brain stimulation on cognitive function, emotion and life quality in patients with severe AD.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial interventions are deep brain stimulation (DBS) and cervical deep lymphatic‑venous anastomosis (LVA), i.e., neurosurgical/device and microsurgical procedures rather than any drug (no pharmaceutical agent named in the description). citeturn0search6
Act: Web searches confirm this is a surgical/device study: the trial listing describes DBS and deep cervical LVA as the treatments under investigation. citeturn0search6

Act (LVA evidence): Publications report LVA (deep cervical lymphatic/lymphovenous anastomosis) as a microsurgical procedure proposed to enhance brain lymphatic clearance with preliminary cognitive/biomarker outcomes in small exploratory cohorts. These sources describe LVA as a surgical intervention, not a drug. citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search4

Act (DBS evidence): Literature and cohort studies describe DBS (fornix or nucleus basalis of Meynert targets) as an implanted neurostimulation therapy that can affect cognition and neuropsychiatric symptoms in AD; again this is a device/neurosurgical intervention, not a biologic or small‑molecule drug. citeturn0search5turn0search3
